results.title: Pathways
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, projections, text, audio, bespoke screens, tiered  wooden seating , timber and LED strips
results.brief_description:
A collaboration between artist-filmmaker Jeff Doring and the Ngarinyin Aboriginal Corporation. This spatial installation provides access and insight into the art and culture of the Ngarinyin people. The intention is to record and interpret a broad spectrum of Ngarinyin knowledge and law. The work consists of five discrete and interrelated elements:
1. The Introduction zone: a space consisting of a text, audio, visual introduction to the installation.
2. The Water and Wanjina zone: a corridor with apertures that open on the side to reveal visual works.
3. The Man Blood Law zone: a three screen installation with tiered seating that lies at the end of the Water and Wanjina corridor.
4. The Cave zone: an exhibition space which spatially represents a cave with images projected inside it.
5. The Today zone: a space which provides a contemporary perspective on the exhibition via a web installation.

results.title: Taking control
results.description:
The women in Thelma & Louise and Promising Young Woman seek their own justice because society won’t believe or listen to them. When the system fails, they fight back. The characters on this screen are part of that cinematic tradition, which stretches from exploitation films like Foxy Brown (1974) and Ms .45 (1982) to today. In that time, female characters have triumphed despite being disbelieved. Ripley (Sigourney Weaver) could have avoided killing the queen in Aliens (1986) if the men in the first film had listened to her warnings. In Terminator 2: Judgement Day (1991), Sarah Connor has to escape an asylum because no one believes she averted an AI apocalypse in the first film.

These future visions are grounded in the past and present. The women in The Nightingale (2018) and The Drover’s Wife (2021) arm themselves against male violence and racism in colonial Australia. But strength is more than physical. Law and Order: SVU’s Olivia Benson (Mariska Hargitay) puts the “lights out” of her attacker but also fights for victims, while Once Were Warriors (1994) follows Beth (Rena Owen) learning she can “survive anything” after tragedy. In A Fantastic Woman (2017), a trans woman battles a legal system that discriminates against her and in Total Control (2019–) Senator Alex Irving (Deborah Mailman) stands up to her political opponents, knowing her push for social justice is “bigger” than their rivalry.
description_for_label:
The women in Thelma & Louise and Promising Young Woman seek their own justice because society won’t believe or listen to them. When the system fails, they fight back. The characters on this screen are part of that cinematic tradition, which stretches from exploitation films like Foxy Brown (1974) and Ms .45 (1982) to today. In that time, female characters have triumphed despite being disbelieved. Ripley (Sigourney Weaver) could have avoided killing the queen in Aliens (1986) if the men in the first film had listened to her warnings. In Terminator 2: Judgement Day (1991), Sarah Connor has to escape an asylum because no one believes she averted an AI apocalypse in the first film.

These future visions are grounded in the past and present. The women in The Nightingale (2018) and The Drover’s Wife (2021) arm themselves against male violence and racism in colonial Australia. But strength is more than physical. Law and Order: SVU’s Olivia Benson (Mariska Hargitay) puts the “lights out” of her attacker but also fights for victims, while Once Were Warriors (1994) follows Beth (Rena Owen) learning she can “survive anything” after tragedy. In A Fantastic Woman (2017), a trans woman battles a legal system that discriminates against her and in Total Control (2019–) Senator Alex Irving (Deborah Mailman) stands up to her political opponents, knowing her push for social justice is “bigger” than their rivalry.

results.title: Police horses: who cares?
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Reg Boulter and Vivian McWaters
results.brief_description:
Film opens with countryside shots at dawn and then goes into a fast-paced montage sequence of Police Horses in action with a funk soundtrack. Features footage of the horses in country, urban and city settings.

The work of a Victorian Department of Agriculture vet is then spotlighted as he tends to injured horses in the field and in a surgery/lab. Includes footage of a horse being X-Rayed who has an injured hoof.

Switches to the Victorian Police band in action and a their drum-carrying horse. Shots of kids enjoying the band play in an outdoor parade.

Then goes to show a Police Horse trainer at work at the Attwood Department of Agriculture stables. In the background of this training sequence planes from the nearby airport take-off and land in the background.

Similar training seqeunce takes place at the St Kilda Rd barracks with four horses being ridden. Up-beat synthesiser soundtrack. City-scape in the background, featuring the National Gallery of Victoria. This is followed by a more formal performance with full dress uniforms and big-band music. Horses and riders then escort the Queen as she travels in a car on parade down two city streets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Reg Boulter and Vivian McWaters

results.title: Report on Eppalock
results.creator_credit: Robert Rothols, Soil Conservation Authority of Victoria and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Lake Eppalock, and its catchment area are the base for a unique water and soil conservation scheme. The area in the past has suffered severe erosion due to gold mining and bad farming. The aims of this long term project are to heal erosion, conserve water, reclaim land and increase farming production with the co-operation of land holders, shire councils and various Government departments.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Rothols, Soil Conservation Authority of Victoria and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

results.title: On the land (i)
results.brief_description:
Fast-paced montage of general farm and animal imagery. Seems to be the title sequence for a television series. Ends with a superimposed title. End of reel features an alternative superimposition that reads ‘On the Land S-TV8’.
Soundtrack is comprised solely of up-beat orchestral music.

results.title: A Dairyland Romance
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Keith Harrison and Jack Keane
results.brief_description:
Story revolves around the importance of choosing breeding partners that have good breeding themselves and the benefits that this will bring their offspring. It stars two cows with human characteristics (standing on two legs, wearing clothes, speaking english, etc.) being interviewed about their successful partnership together and goes on to give information on correct rearing techniques. Hand-painted animation looks suberb and the deadpan delivery of the main charcaters is very amusing.

Illustrated ‘The End’ and opening titles.

results.title: The Voice of Agriculture
results.creator_credit: Tony Doogood and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, this short film is an advertisement for the radio broadcast “The Voice of Agriculture”. Typical of the (now outdated) representation of gender roles of the time, the film opens with a domestic scene in which the mother of the family is making dinner while her husband discusses farm work. The farmer, who is having trouble with his sheep, calls on professional help from a veterinarian at the Department of Agriculture, who informs him about the radio program “The Voice of Agriculture”, which is designed to help farmers like him. The film then shows the behind-the-scenes production of the broadcast, including voice actors, radio technicians and vintage wireless sets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Doogood and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

The farmer, who is having trouble with his sheep, calls on professional help from a veterinarian at the Department of Agriculture, who informs him about the radio program “The Voice of Agriculture”, which is designed to help farmers like him. The film then shows the behind-the-scenes production of the broadcast, including voice actors, radio technicians and vintage wireless sets.

results.title: Tomatoes for processing
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane, Rod Kefford, Ann Millard and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description:
Film begins with instructions on how to garner and prepare tomato seeds for planting, before focusing on the seed germination process and how to cultivate a good crop of seedlings.

The seedlings are then uprooted and planted in larger fields. Manual and semi-automatic seedling planting techniques are shown using different types of machinery.

When fully grown the tomatoes are picked and packed into wooden crates. Film details the correct picking and packing process.

Finally, the tomatoes are taken to a factory, where they are pulped and made into tomato sauce.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Keane, Rod Kefford, Ann Millard and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

Finally, the tomatoes are taken to a factory, where they are pulped and made into tomato sauce.
